intro: Acridocarpus alopecurus subsp. pubescens, commonly known as the hairy mouse-ear cress, is a member of the Brassicaceae family. It is a low-growing perennial plant characterized by its small, rounded leaves that are covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, yellow flowers arranged in clusters, which are typical of the mustard family. It thrives in moist, temperate environments and is often found in meadows and along stream banks. Its hairy foliage and compact growth make it easily distinguishable from other similar species.
